Hipposideros armiger, commonly known as the Himalayan leaf-nosed bat, is a species of bat belonging to the family Hipposideridae. It is native to the Himalayan regions of South Asia, including parts of India, Nepal, Bhutan, and China.

The Himalayan leaf-nosed bat is a medium-sized bat, with a head-body length ranging from 80 to 105 millimeters and a wingspan of 450 to 560 millimeters. It has distinctive leaf-like nasal appendages, which are thought to play a role in echolocation and sensory perception. The species has a robust build, with a broad head and large, rounded ears.

These bats typically roost in caves, rock crevices, and abandoned buildings, often in small to medium-sized colonies. They are known to be highly adaptable and can be found in a variety of habitats, including forests, grasslands, and human-modified landscapes.

The Himalayan leaf-nosed bat is an insectivorous species, feeding primarily on moths, beetles, and other small insects. It uses its echolocation abilities to locate and capture prey in flight.

The conservation status of the Himalayan leaf-nosed bat is classified as "Least Concern" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as the species is widely distributed and has a relatively stable population.
